column1: Nippon Foundation Ocean Nexus Center at UW EarthLab -- Research Projects as of 2 February 2022
Title
column2: PI(institution)
column7: Description

column1: Equity Considerations in Ocean Governance: The Role of the Blue Economy
column2:
Ana Spalding,
Oregon State University (Marine and Coastal Policy)
column7: This project will explore how the blue economy (including ocean industries such as fisheries, transportation, energy, and tourism) is being woven into national and international perspectives on the future of ocean governance under a sustainable development agenda. We will develop a case study in the Eastern Tropical Pacific Coast (ETP) of Panama to address broader questions concerning inclusivity and social equity in ocean governance.

column1: Indigenous Scholarship Approach and its Application to MPA Design
column2:
Ana Spalding,
Oregon State University (Marine and Coastal Policy)
column7: This project will look into Indigenous scholarship applied to examine how spatial management models (ICCA, OECM, and IPLC) respect the interests of Indigenous communities and their traditional tenure systems. In this context, Indigenous scholarship indicates studies of and by Indigenous peoples. Regions will be Oceanian islands, in particular, French Polynesia, Fiji, and Samoa. This study is in collaboration with Chris McOwen at UNEP-WCMC.

column1: Understanding social outcomes and enabling conditions for Marine Protected Area effectiveness
column2:
Ana Spalding,
Oregon State University (Marine and Coastal Policy)
column7: In advance of the official announcement of a new global spatial conservation target of 30% by 2030, several countries have claimed that they had already achieved this target. However, achieving this target spatially says little about the effectiveness of protections or how it affects coastal populations. Furthermore, not all MPAs are the same: they can range from fully protected ‚Äòno-take‚Äô areas to sites with minimal protection that allow extractive activities; and, frequently, protections are unequally distributed in space and time. As such, this project seems to further explore innovative and comprehensive ways to assess MPA effectiveness, rather than simply quantifying them in number and spatial extent. Specific activities include improved assessment (and communication) of social outcomes, and a process to emphasize the need for and application of best conditions for desired MPA outcomes including ensuring an equitable and just social, cultural, and regulatory context as well as accessible and inclusive knowledge and information sharing.

column1: Blue Economy Implementation and Social Equity
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: This project looks at the contrasts between Blue Economy focused on financial growth versus on equity and local objectives. This will provide clarification of existing Blue Economy narratives and develop quantitative metrics to underpin Blue Economy development across scales and contexts.

column1: Concepts of fishing community
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: This project investigates the contemporary use of "fishing community" in literature, particularly in Latin America. A key argument to be explored is that the unspecific and uncritical use of this concept to refer to locations, communities of practice, industries, etc., may lead to muddled, inequitable, and potentially contradictory recommendations for prioritizing policy actions and research.

column1: Fisher Vulnerabilities
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: This research aims to test, using available quantitative data, whether we can see negative impacts on fishers in places that have been identified as being vulnerable to climate change, overfishing, etc. This will help us confront assumptions on vulnerability with available quantitative evidence, and identify gaps in available data itself.

column1: Future Ocean Scenario
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: This paper will be based on results from a draft Nereus report on disparity and will explore a transformative scenario planning approach.

column1: Global Diving Benefits
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: The first component of this research will be to estimate the yearly global economic contributions of the diving and snorkelling industry. Throughout that stage of research, we will lay the groundwork for addressing the second component, how and if those economic benefits flow to local communities.

column1: Marine Renewable Energy and Coastal Communities
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: Understanding the scale of potential contributions of marine renewable energy to coastal communities that are off grid. While current discussions are focused on large-scale grid systems of marine renewable energy, there has been little success due to the high costs. This research frames marine renewable energy as an alternative under SDGs for off grid coastal communities.

column1: Ocean Development Policies for Economic and Social Wellbeing in Coastal Communities
column2:
AndrÈs Cisneros-Montemayor,
Simon Fraser University (School of Resource and Environmental Management)
column7: This project aims to identify and analyze a suite of potential development policies that would help secure social and economic wellbeing in coastal communities. An important part of this work involves the testing of wellbeing indicators for coastal regions and industries, and potential development of new indicators where appropriate.

column1: Review of gender and feminist theory in Marine Social Science
column2:
Annet Pauwelussen, 
Wageningen University & Research (Forest and Nature Conservation Policy Group)
column7: This project reviews marine social science literature on how gender and feminist theory is articulated and applied. The results are situated in a broader framework of feminist and gender theory in environmental studies, to analyze what kind of feminist theory and notions of gender are dominant or marginal in marine social science, and how this affects the way gender equity is framed in marine science and policy.

column1: Understanding Gendered Inequities in Ocean Restoration Policy and Practice
column2:
Annet Pauwelussen, 
Wageningen University & Research (Forest and Nature Conservation Policy Group)
column7: This project reviews eco-feminist, queer and decolonial scholarship and explores how these can help rethink and reimagine human-ocean relations in ways responsive to different ways of knowing and relating to the ocean. In particular, the study focuses on ocean restoration as celebrated nature-based solution to environmental degradation of ocean life. Using feminist decolonial theory, the project: 1) critically reflects on established notions of nature and care in ocean restoration programs, and its friction with situated human-ocean entanglements, including indigenous understandings thereof, 2) examines how epistemological and ontological asymmetries (ways of knowing and enacting the ocean) are sustained in ocean restoration, and 3) explores and develops experimental methodologies that foster dialogues across difference for ocean rehabilitation to be practiced on (more) equitable terms.

column1: Data for Decision-making in Coastal Communities
column2:
Araba Sey, 
University of Washington (Information School)
column7: This project explores how the processes that build and use data (in its varied forms and definitions) for decision-making can be more inclusive of populations that have traditionally been excluded or minimized from these processes. It focuses on tools that can be grounded in communities' self-identified needs and epistemologies, with an emphasis on the role of community organizations in leading local efforts to increase inclusion.

column1: MPA, Climate Change and Coastal Communities
column2:
Chris McOwen & Bob Smith,
World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC) and University of Kent
column7: The overarching objective of this project will be to develop a quantitative framework for incorporating climate change into systematic conservation planning. The approach should seek practical solutions to develop/measure overlap between current and likely future ecological states within a planned MPA network. Approaches that incorporate climate change into existing conservation planning, such as with decision support tools like Marxan, are timely as nations progress towards achieving Aichi Target 11 and expand their MPA networks. In collaboration with the Bedford Institute of Oceanography.

column1: MPA, Climate Change and Coastal Communities
column2:
Chris McOwen & Bob Smith,
World Conservation Monitoring Centre (UNEP-WCMC) and University of Kent
column7: The overarching objective of this project will be to develop a quantitative framework for incorporating climate change into systematic conservation planning. The approach should seek practical solutions to develop/measure overlap between current and likely future ecological states within a planned MPA network. Approaches that incorporate climate change into existing conservation planning, such as with decision support tools like Marxan, are timely as nations progress towards achieving Aichi Target 11 and expand their MPA networks. In collaboration with the Bedford Institute of Oceanography.

column1: Ocean and Public Health
column2:
Elaine Faustman, 
University of Washington (School of Public Health)
column7: A key focus of the project is on developing and recognizing wellbeing as critical component in public health. Risk-based framing can be used as an organizing concept to include nutritional,social, economic, and cultural contributions. An example of this project will be to develop an integrated approach to reconsider the understanding of wellbeing tied to seafood consumption and advisories for women of childbearing age. Women‚Äôs health and education are linked with family wellbeing and population resilience.

column1: Public health Implications of Changing Ocean State
column2:
Elaine Faustman, 
University of Washington (School of Public Health) Supported by Jill Falman, University of Washington (School of Public Health)
column7: This project will use public health risk-based frameworks to identify effects on susceptible populations (mothers and children, small place-based communities) and apply community-based assessments (bottom-up approach) to define wellbeing. The initial step will be to identify critical missing data and knowledge gaps and the differences in metrics used to support oceans and human health decisions. Included in these, would be both gender, age, and place-based decision analytics. Additionaly, using risk based frameworks allows us to examine a variety of ocean impacts, helps to facilitate this dialogue, and identify important points for intervention and policy implications. Considerations of wellbeing and cultural context frequently use semi-quantitative metrics and non-traditional knowledge for informing risk-based decisions. These are commonly lost in research, policy dialogues, and decisions.

column1: Cultural Tipping Point of the Ocean
column2:
Elsie Sunderland,
Harvard University (Department of Environmental Health)
column7: This project seeks to formalize the role of cultural identity, which has been underrepresented in socio-ecological systems frameworks. This systems model for integrated social-ecological systems will be based on a case study of the impacts of global pollutants on the Faroe Islands.

column1: Global Change and Risk in Ocean Decisions
column2:
Gerald Singh,
Memorial University of Newfoundland (Department of Geography)
column7: Failure of aquaculture industries may lead to the loss of a country's whole economy, especially coastal communities. That's why it is essential to make our blue economy more resilient, which demands innovations such as farmed aquacultures designed to be resistant to sudden climate change.¬† Digital tools are needed which can help aquaculture industries to adjust to ever-changing conditions in the oceans. Federal and provisional governments need to provide financial protections to fish farming companies to protect them from catastrophic losses. This project aims to understand 1) how climate change affects the blue economy and how it can be made more resilient to coop such challenges. 2) how the use of technology and rigorous policymaking can help protect the livelihoods of families and aquaculture companies that are in danger of losing to a rapidly changing climate. Considering these two aspects, we can avoid a climate disaster to our blue economy.

column1: SDGs and Global Change: EIA/SEA - Development-driven Sustainable Development
column2:
Gerald Singh,
Memorial University of Newfoundland (Department of Geography)
column7: This project will be exploring and improving the use of environmental assessment and EIA as a tool for sustainable development.

column1: SDGs and Global Change: MPAs - Conservation-driven Sustainable Development
column2:
Gerald Singh,
Memorial University of Newfoundland (Department of Geography)
column7: This project will be expanding the scope of MPA evaluation and planning for social, economic, and governance equity concerns. The work on sustainable development goals will largely focus on determining how to structure policy to help achieve goals, and identifying potential trade-offs that might stymie progress.

column1: SDGs and Global Change: Strategic Priorities for SDG Attainment
column2:
Gerald Singh,
Memorial University of Newfoundland (Department of Geography)
column7: This project seeks to answer the following questions: How does global change contribute to/detract from attaining SDGs? Where can policy promote attaining SDGs given global change? What policy processes can promote SDG attainment without facing social barriers to implementation? The focus of this study is on coastal communities, especially small-scale fishing communities.

column1: Policy Analysis
column2:
Grant Blume,
University of Washington (Evans School of Public Policy and Governance)
column7: This project will be a collaborative process with Nexus Pis and Fellows to conduct policy analysis per applicable Nexus projects.

column1: Decent Work and Social Responsibility in the World's Fisheries
column2:
Jack Kittinger,
Arizona State University (Global Institute of Sustainability)
column7: This project will look into the underlying causes and enabling conditions that produce labor abuses in fisheries, as well as those that enable decent work. The project will also examine the interconnectedness between labor issues, overfishing, and other forms of illegality at sea. The study will draw on the International Labour Organization's (ILO) Fundamental Principles and Rights at Work, the ILO Convention on Work in Fishing (C188), and ILO indicators of decent work to develop a holistic methodology for studying, defining and promoting decent work in fisheries. The ultimate goal is to develop the foundations for a more balanced global assessment of human and labor rights abuses in fisheries, moving us beyond the geographic focus of many recent initiatives (e.g., on Southeast Asia), and directly informing policy solutions and action agendas at multiple scales. This year, the focus will be on developing an in-depth case study on the Humboldt squid (Dosidicus gigas) fishery in Peru.

column1: Adapting Research Methodologies in the COVID-19 Pandemic
column2:
Kate Barclay,
University of Technology Sydney (Fisheries, Maritimes and Coastal Studies)
column7: This project will develop a resource for doctoral and postdoctoral researchers employing qualitative or mixed methods, whose work is being affected by the current measures in place worldwide restricting mobility, gatherings of people, and face-to-face meetings for interviews.

column1: Ocean Equity
column2:
Kate Crosman & Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington
column7: This project will define what "equity" means in the ocean context, based on an equity framework with contribution by Nexus Pis and through literature review.

column1: Social Psychology
column2:
Kate Crosman,
University of Washington
column7: This project will be a critique to the social psychology application to ocean governance.

column1: Understanding the Inclusion and Structuring of European Small-Scale Coastal Fishers within Producers Organizations
column2:
Mathieu Colleter,
Institut National Polytechnique de Toulouse - Ecole Nationale Superieure Agronomique de Toulouse / IDDRI
column7: This project will investigate the new development of Producer Organisations for and by small-scale fishers. Producer Organisations represent important policy and representation instruments in the EU (as regarding market organization, subsidies, participation in decision-making processes and consultations). There is a need to understand why and how small-scale fishers seize (or not) this policy instrument, as well as the challenges they encounter in doing so.

column1: An inventory of small-scale fisheries organizations in North America
column2:
Megan Bailey & Wilf Swartz, 
Dalhousie University (Marine Affairs Program)
column7: This project will produce an inventory or database of most of the small-scale fisheries organizations in North America. The database will provide a summary of key characteristics of each organization, such as the history, membership demographic, legal status, and function and role in fisheries management. This information will provide a baseline understanding of how fisheries stakeholders organize themselves for internal and external activities in fisheries management. These organizations can provide a wealth of knowledge on historical fishing practices, local ecological knowledge and practical solutions for sustainable fisheries.

column1: Economic impact of Covid-19 on fisheries
column2:
Megan Bailey & Wilf Swartz, 
Dalhousie University (Marine Affairs Program)
column7: This project will conduct a survey to paint a rich picture on a fine scale of fisheries workers‚Äô current economic situation. Some of the main questions the survey will help answer include: if fisheries workers have been able to work this year, how their employment and income have been impacted, and if and how current assistance programs play a role in their lives.

column1: Government COVID-19 Response Measures to Assist the Fisheries Sector
column2:
Megan Bailey & Wilf Swartz, 
Dalhousie University (Marine Affairs Program)
column7: This project will seek to understand the measures that governments have implemented to support the fisheries sector through obstacles related to COVID-19. Government support measures such as grants, credit agreements, waivers, and other efforts to protect and promote fisheries will be discussed. Efforts directed at the fisheries sector as well as fisheries eligibility for non-specific measures will be explored.

column1: WTO Negotiation for International Regulations of Fisheries Subsidies
column2:
Megan Bailey & Wilf Swartz, 
Dalhousie University (Marine Affairs Program)
column7: A review of the positions taken by various member states at WTO's fisheries subsidies negotiation post-SDG.

column1: China‚Äôs evolving role in global oceans
column2:
Mike Fabinyi & Kate Barclay,
University of Technology Sydney (Fisheries, Maritimes and Coastal Studies)
column7: This project will look into what challenges and opportunities are associated with China's evolving role in global ocean governance, bilateral trade in fisheries, maritime policies, and other aspects of marine social sciences.  Our studies will examine the implications of China‚Äôs ocean interests for other countries in terms of equity in ocean governance.

column1: Indigenous Ocean Ecologies
column2:
P Joshua Griffin, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column6:
Graduate Fellow: 
 Izzy Lavallee
 
Undergraduate Fellows: 
 Autumn Forespring, 
 Isa Whalen, 
 Sesilina Lane, 
 Sierra Red Bow, 
 Stephanie Masterman
column7: This project will support community-engaged research projects at the intersections of Indigenous sovereignty, wellbeing, and environmental justice. In 2020-21, PI Griffin will facilitate a year-long seminar and ‚Äúresearch family‚Äù among fellows, in collaboration with the UW Center for American Indian and Indigenous Studies and the Department of American Indian Studies.

column1: Allocation and RFMOs
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: This paper updates and summarises the current state of allocations and negotiations of key RFMOs.

column1: Blue colonialism and marine conservation
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: PhD on the relationship and impacts of colonialism and marine conservation

column1: Catch Attribution
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6: Ruth Davis, Quentin Hanich, Wilf Swartz, Andres Cisneros,  Kamal Azmi, Katy Seto, Tim Adams, Mathieu Colletier
column7: Catch attribution, coastal State sovereignty and equity

column1: Climate Change and Revenue
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6: Johann Bell, Quentin Hanich, Harriet Harden-Davies, Yoshi Ota, Katy Seto
column7: Climate-driven redistribution of tuna threatens to disrupt the economies of Pacific Small Island Developing States (SIDS) and sustainable management of the world‚Äôs largest tuna fishery. Study shows that by 2050, under a high greenhouse gas emissions scenario (RCP 8.5), the total biomass of three tuna species in the waters of ten Pacific SIDS could decline by an average of 13% due to a greater proportion of fish occurring in the high seas. The potential implications for Pacific Island economies in 2050 include an average decline in purse-seine catch of 20%, an average annual loss in regional tuna-fishing access fees of US$90 million and reductions in government revenue of up to 13% for individual Pacific SIDS. Responses include negotiating within the regional fisheries management organization to maintain the present-day benefits they receive from tuna, regardless of the effects of climate change on the distribution of the fish.

column1: Compatibility
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: This project explores the compatibility of measures between EEZs and High Seas is critical to sustainability and equity. Specifically, this paper looks into the management of fisheries across jurisdictions. There is a need to recognize sovereign rights and protect the aspirations of coastal states.

column1: Collective Power: The Pacific Way
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: This book analyses and discusses the development of regional fisheries management and development in the Western and Central Pacific Ocean, with the purpose of fostering the expansion and further development of collective strategies, science-based approaches and true ocean stewardship. The book focuses on the Pacific, but synthesises and extrapolates lessons learnt, providing stories and tools to support the successful negotiation of future equitable and sustainable solutions in the Pacific, and other oceans and environmental conflicts.

column1: Decade of Ocean Science
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6:
Harriet Harden-Davies
 Randa Sacedon
 Ruth Davis
column7: This study looks into 1) the role of science in decision-making for biodiversity conservation, management and sustainable use at the international level; 2) mechanisms used to develop a science-based approach for sustainable and equitable use of marine resources; 3) the role of science in capacity-building to enable implementation of international decisions; and 4) the role of science diplomacy in contributing to inclusive innovation and informed decision-making (e.g., UN Decade of Ocean Science).

column1: Equity and Transboundary Fisheries
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: PhD on Indo-Pacific RFMOs and Equity

column1: High seas: Equality and Equity in Conservation, Resources, Knowledge and Stewardship
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6:
Harriet Harden-Davies
 Yoshi Ota
 Gerald Singh
 Bianca Haas
 Ruth Davis
 Kamal Azmi
 Randa Sacedon
 Others
column7: This study will examine theroetical and practical frameworks to develop a decision-making process. Redress for colonial legacy and true equality of States requires equitable distributions of global common pool resources, conservation, knowledge and stewardship.

column1: Legal Framework to Support Traditional Knowledge / knowing
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: PhD on Ocean Governance and Traditional Knowledge

column1: Nature, Rights and Equity
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: This project will be a new study to follow on from Rights of Nature paper - looking at how rights of nature laws are implemented in practice and whether such laws enable greater participation of local communities in decision-making.

column1: Negotiations MOOC
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6:
Ruth Davis
 Kamal Azmi
 Harriet Harden-Davies
 Others
column7: International negotiations requires more than American-business derived 'sales' approach to negotiations. ANCORS will develop course materials and courses for Indo-Pacific officials and stakeholders to support collective barfgaining and advocacy for equitable outcomes. Courses will inclde both closed and open (free MOOCs)

column1: Policy Coherence
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6:
Randa Sacedon
 Bianca Haas
 Kamal Azmi
 Ruth Davis
 Katy Seto
 Gerald Singh
 Others
column7: This study will identify inconsistencies and contradictions between DWFN‚Äôs support for SDGs, particularly SDG14, and the behaviour of their fisheries delegations during RFMO negotiations, and the impact of this behaviour on the development aspirations, food security and revenue of small islands developing States in the Indo-Pacific.

column1: Rights of Nature
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: In this paper, we consider how a Rights of Nature perspective might inform the development of a new international legal instrument for biodiversity beyond national jurisdiction (BBNJ agreement). We examine Rights of Nature laws and identify four characteristics relating to: i) rights; ii) connectivity; iii) reciprocity; and iv) representation and implementation. We argue that a Rights of Nature perspective can reinforce existing ocean governance norms, inspire new measures to enhance the effectiveness and equitability of the BBNJ agreement and enable global ocean stewardship in ABNJ.

column1: SIDS, Scientist Capacity and Benefits from MGRs
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column6:
Harriet Harden-Davies
 Marjo Vierros
 Yoshi Ota
 Others
column7: Development of BBNJ agreement offers timely opportunity to understand the challenges facing SIDS to benefit equitably from science and innovation involving high seas biodiversity, as well as keys to success for partnerships and capacity building approaches. This study involves conducting interviews and desktop resarch.

column1: Transparency and Governance
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: International and regional organisations promote transparency on the basis that it can improve the sustainability of fisheries, yet the processes involved, and the outcomes of transparency initiatives, are often opaque and misunderstood. This study examines efforts to improve transparency in the tuna fisheries of the Pacific Island region, with our analysis focusing on members of the Pacific Islands Forum, excluding metropolitan countries New Zealand and Australia. It draws on a tripartite framework to examine transparency initiatives and outcomes associated with the Pacific Islands' tuna fisheries. It finds that efforts to improve transparency have mainly focused on increasing or sustaining economic gains for the region‚Äôs governments but much less on enhancing transparency of policy-making, decision-making and policy outcomes, especially at the domestic level. Weaknesses in regional and national institutions, and concerns about corruption, overfishing, and sustainability persist. We argue that to improve transparency and sustainability in the fisheries of the Pacific Island region, policy makers and researchers need to better understand and respond to the multiple interests and actors shaping behaviour in the tuna fisheries between different administrative scales.

column1: Transparency in Decision-Making
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: The adoption of effective fisheries conservation and management measures (‚ÄòCMM‚Äô) represents a critical stage in the process of sustainably managing global fishing stocks. It represents the point at which scientific data is integrated with law and policy considerations to generate concrete rules designed to constrain the behaviour of fishers and other stakeholders in order to promote desired conservation goals within a fishery. This paper will examine the fisheries CMM process within the broader framework of international law and policy for marine resource governance. It will consider transparency aspects at key stages of the CMM process including the gathering and sharing of data upon which measures are based, the tabling and negotiation of new measures in RFMO meetings, through to the monitoring and enforcement of CMM to ensure their implementation. At each stage, the paper will seek to explore the potential for transparency initiatives to improve the effectiveness of fisheries CMM in promoting desired conservation and management goals within a fishery.

column1: WCPFC Interests
column2:
Quentin Hanich, 
University of Wollongong (Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources & Security)
column7: This study provides analysis of benefits for decision-makers on equitable benefit sharing and avoidance of a disproportionate burden, which requires data on existing benefits and analysis of impacts of alternative measures.

column1: Brexit, Devolution and the Sea
column2:
Richard Caddell, 
Cardiff University (School of Law)
column7: This project will map for the first time the transfer of marine regulatory powers from the central UK government to the devolved administrations and their application under the laws and principles applicable within the constituent countries of the UK. In so doing, this project will identify areas of regulatory divergence, and the emergence of specific marine laws applicable to these nations. This project will also consider the impacts of Brexit in this process and the repatriation of key powers from the EU to the UK and in turn the devolved administrations, with a particular focus on fisheries management, marine pollution issues and nature conservation. This projct will also consider the UK's maritme relationships with its overseas territories and Crown Dependencies, notably the Channel Islands. In so doing this project seeks to provide the first panoramic view of regulation within UK jurisdictional waters - or perhaps more accurately, the waters of the UK's various jurisdictions

column1: Human Societies in the Caribbean
column2:
Russell Fielding, 
Coastal Carolina University
column7: This project investigates the relevant environmental and human health effects of whaling in the Caribbean through the collection and analysis of whale tissue samples, human hair samples, dietary data, and health histories from volunteer participants. Whalers from St. Vincent & the Grenadines (SVG) take small cetaceans for human consumption at the average rate of 344 cetaceans per year. The foods produced contain concentrations of mercury that far exceed international recommendations: mean THg concentrations in muscle tissue range from 3.22 to 48.4 Œºg/g wet weight by species, while the relevant FAO/WHO limit is 1.0 Œºg/g. Whale-based food products are part of the diet of a majority (77%) of SVG residents. Working closely with SVG government health officials, project collaborators hope to positively impact healthy food production strategies in this small-island developing state.

column1: Monitoring Ocean Acidification Impact on Oyster Farms in Japan
column2:
Ryan Kelly & Terrie Klinger,
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7: This project seeks to apply the lessons learned from the WA state Blue Ribbon Panel on Ocean Acidifcation to develop an actionable, exportable tool kit to connect available OA information to shellfish aquaculture and governance decision-making, Satoumi research institute in Japan: working on OA-Aquaculture project in Japan. Questions that will be addressed are: How can coastal resource users and industries adapt to Ocean Acidification? To what extent is acidification of the Seto Sea driven by CO2 vs. by other inputs? How can locally-collected water chemistry monitoring data (e.g., pH) be used to enable marine resource users (e.g., seaweed growers) to make informed decisions? How does adaptation to acidification change when no large, industrial players drive the adaptation process?

column1: Economic Security and Safety Nets in Coastal Communities
column2:
Wilf Swartz,
Dalhousie University (Marine Affairs Program)
column7: This research aims to identify the social safety net mechanisms in place  to support fishers and coastal communities in France by analyzing the links and functions of various private and semi-private fisheries institutions. The results will provide insights  on how safety nets can be improved to make French fishers and fishing communities more resilient to economic, social and environmental perturbations.

column1: Climate Change Adaptation and Small Scale Fisheries
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7: This project will focus on sustainable seafood, food sovereignty and security in light of climate change. Specifically, it will examine financial support for climate adaptation available to fishing communities. In particular we will be focusing on financial mechanisms globally (from intergovernmental, national and non-governmental agencies) available to support smallscale fisheries to address the issues related to climate change.

column1: Considering Ontological Multiplicities in Relation to Marine Conservation Efforts
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7: This research aims to evaluate the spiritual pluralisms that exist across communities and how these beliefs may influence the implementation and success of local marine conservation efforts. Using a multicultural and decolonial lens, this study critically examines the compatibility and incongruencies between local communities and environmental protection regulations facilitated by centralized government systems, with the hope of emphasizing cultural and biological diversity. While focusing on the epistemologies and ontologies of local community members, the behavior and goals of management efforts are also considered to highlight the importance of co-management and acknowledge the diversity of perspectives and methodologies fostering ecosystem protection and cultural needs.

column1:
Fish Scales: The Production of Scale Mismatch and Inequity
in Tuna Fisheries Management
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7:
This project will critically examine the role of scale and scalar 
assumptions in tuna management. Tuna management is currently undertaken by five tuna regional fisheries management organizations (TRFMOs). These intergovernmental organizations bring together coastal and fishing states to deliberate on the conservation and management of regional tuna stocks. It is widely assumed that the TRFMO system addresses a scale mismatch between the regional distribution of tuna stocks and international participation in tuna fisheries by vessels flagged to multiple states. This project challenges the assumption that the TRFMO system solves scale mismatch. Instead, this project will use a critical conception of scale to investigate how scale is produced and contested through the TRFMO system, with particular equity consequences for tuna management. The project will center around three case studies of tuna stocks that problematize scalar assumptions in TRFMO management. These stocks are socio-economically significant to bordering developing coastal states and have limited subregional distributions. By analyzing how each case study is impacted by scalar assumptions, this project will shed light on the role scale plays in the effectiveness and equitability of the TRFMO system.

column1: Marine Renewable Energy's Potential to Contribute to the UN Sustainable Development Goals
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7: The goal of this project is to 1) understand the connection between impacts from potential hydrokinetic marine renewable energy development and SDGs targets; and 2) estimate the potential scale and location of impacts on SDGs for developing nations from hydrokinetic marine renewable energy. The locations, populations, and scale of impacts from marine renewable energy on a global level have not been estimated. Understanding these interactions will enable the sector to anticipate potential impacts of technology development, while also harnessing the power of the ocean to ensure sustainable development goals are addressed.

column1: Migration, Development and Fisheries
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7: This research will conduct a literature review on migration, coastal development and fisheries to prepare for a larger research. More specifically, the focus will be on West African migration to look into coastal migration and development workers. What are the conditions like for migrated fisheries? Who are they?

column1: Migration of Coastal Communities
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column7: This research seeks to identify the ways climate change and the oceans affect people, especially where migration and security are involved. Policymakers often view immigration in terms of quotas or statistics, but the migrants are often diverse in their cultures, job and livelihood needs, understanding of risk, and future adaptive capacities that laws and regulations simply cannot be a one size fits all. The hope for this research is to study how people, especially those in coastal communities, recognize the need for migration and establish plans. Fieldwork is anticipated in the Asian and Pacific Island regions, such as the Philippines.

column1: SeaWeaver: Bio-inhabitable Woven Structures for Coastal Ecosystem Restoration
column2:
Yoshi Ota, 
University of Washington (School of Marine and Environmental Affairs)
column6: This project aims to combat the negative effects of marine habitat loss and biodiversity. The initial aim of this project was to address the decline of seaweed forest ecosystems through integrating the seaweed-growing abilities of rope-based seaweed agriculture with the modular design systems of traditional weaving crafts and tensile architecture. The project has since expanded in scope to develop SeaWeaver as a framework to develop concepts specific to a variety of coastal ecosystems, most significantly those of tropical coral reefs and seagrass beds. Since this transition, the next step has been developing testable concepts and building connections to get them installed into those environments for testing.¬†
column7: This project aims to combat the negative effects of marine habitat loss and biodiversity. Techniques from seaweed rope-farming will be combined with traditional weaving crafts to develop a low-cost, low-density underwater structure that supports the growth of marine plants and the ecosystems around them. This structure will be placed in areas that have suffered from habitat loss, and bring biodiversity back into vacated waters.
